explanation: Reasoning based on nearby Rb2M F6 analogues in the dataset. Most Rb2M F6 (M = Ni, Mn, Cu, Pd, V, Sn, Cr...) have nearly cubic cells with a ≈ 8.35–8.73 Å and volumes ≈ 580–665 Å^3; averaging the Rb2-series (Rb2NiF6, Rb2MnF6, Rb2CuF6, Rb2PdF6, Rb2VF6) gives a lattice constant ≈ 8.426 Å and volume ≈ 598 Å^3, so I predict Rb2CoF6 will adopt a similar cell (a ≈ b ≈ c ≈ 8.43 Å, V ≈ 598 Å^3). Formation energies for Co-containing A2CoF6 entries (K2CoF6 and Cs2CoF6) are very similar (≈ -2.47 eV/atom), and many Rb2M F6 formation energies cluster around -2.3 to -3.1 eV/atom, so I predict a formation energy ≈ -2.47 eV/atom. For the electronic gap: K2CoF6 is reported ≈ 1.17 eV while Cs2CoF6 is metallic (0 eV); Rb is intermediate in size between K and Cs, so an intermediate, small nonzero gap is likely. I therefore predict a modest semiconducting gap of about 0.8 eV. These values are approximate (expected uncertainty of a few 0.1s of eV for the gap and a few percent for lattice/formation energy) given variations across different B-site cations and possible polymorphism/tetragonal distortions.

Rb sits between K and Cs in ionic size, so Rb2CoF6 should be structurally and energetically similar to K2CoF6 and Cs2CoF6. The formation energies of K2CoF6 (-2.467 eV/atom) and Cs2CoF6 (-2.473 eV/atom) are nearly identical, so I predict a formation energy for the Rb compound essentially the same. Lattice parameters were estimated by interpolating the A-site size effect between the K and Cs analogues and by using a conventional (full) cell volume comparable to other A2MF6 members (K full-cell ≈ 514 Å^3, Cs ≈ 521 Å^3). That gives a roughly cubic cell with a≈8.02 Å (a=b=c) and volume ≈516 Å^3. The band gap for K2CoF6 is ~1.17 eV while the Cs analogue was predicted as metallic (0.0 eV) in the provided data; Rb is expected intermediate, so I predict a small semiconducting gap on the order of ~0.8–1.0 eV. Given DFT variability and different cell representations in the dataset, these values are approximate.

Rb2CoF6 is an Rb2M F6 elpasolite-like compound; lattice sizes for Rb2M F6 in the dataset cluster around a = 8.35–8.50 Å (volumes ~580–615 Å^3). Co4+ ionic radius is similar to Ni4+/Mn4+ so I expect a cell near the midpoint of that cluster. Formation energies for Rb2M F6 range roughly −2.3 to −3.1 eV/atom; Co should be moderately stable like Ni/Mn analogues, so I predict a formation energy a bit more negative than Ni but less than the most negative V/Cr values. Band gaps in the series vary with d electron count: early d1–d2 and some d7 cases show metallic/zero gaps, while d6 Pd/Ni show ~2–2.4 eV and d3 Mn ~3.3 eV. Co4+ is d5 and often gives a small to moderate gap (spin-polarized), so I predict a small semiconductor gap around 1.1 eV. Given variations in oxidation/spin state and possible magnetic/metallic behavior this estimate has substantial uncertainty.

No direct Rb2M F6 entries are present in the training analogues, so I used trends among the provided A2MCl6/A2MBr6/A2MI6 and small-anion compounds to estimate properties. Rb2MCl6-type elpasolite cells in the table have cubic a around ~9.9–10.3 Å (Rb/Cs with Cl); replacing Cl by the much smaller F anion typically contracts the lattice substantially. Scaling by the decreased anion size and comparing to small-anion entries (hydrides, fluorine-like contraction) gives an estimated cubic lattice parameter of ~7.8–8.0 Å (I used 7.85 Å here). Volume is a^3. Band gaps for the chloride/bromide elpasolites in the list are often in the ~0–2.5 eV range; fluorides are more ionic and tend to increase the gap, but Co in a high oxidation state can introduce mid-gap d-states that reduce the gap. Balancing these trends yields a moderate gap estimate of ~2.1 eV. Formation energies per atom for the Rb2MCl6 entries are typically quite negative (~-1.6 to -2.0 eV/atom); fluorides are also strongly bound, so I predict a formation energy similar to the more stable halides, about -1.8 eV/atom. These values are approximate and intended as first-order estimates based on ionic-radius scaling and observed halide trends in the provided data.

Predictions are based on trends in A2B F6 cubic double-perovskite analogues in the provided dataset. Lattice parameter: K2NiF6 and K2MnF6 have a ~8.00–8.07 Å while Cs2NiF6/Cs2MnF6 are ~8.86–8.91 Å; Rb lies between K and Cs in ionic size, so I interpolate to a ~8.45 Å (a = b = c), giving volume = 8.45^3 = 603.35 Å^3. Band gap: Ni-based F6 compounds show gaps ~2.3–2.4 eV, Mn-based ~3.3 eV, while early transition-metal examples (Cr, V) are metallic. Co (likely Co4+ in A2CoF6) is expected to give a smaller but nonzero gap compared with Ni analogues, so I predict a moderate gap ~1.8 eV. Formation energy: most A2MF6 halides in the dataset have formation energies between about -2.3 and -2.9 eV/atom; Co-based should be similar to Ni/Fe analogues, so I estimate ~-2.45 eV/atom (slightly more stable than Ni but less than Mn analogues). These values are approximate and intended as trend-based interpolations, not ab initio results.

Rb2CoF6 is expected to adopt the same cubic (A2B6, K2PtCl6-type / elpasolite-like) motif as many A2MCl6 / A2MF6 analogues in the training set. Fluorides are more compact than chlorides (F- much smaller than Cl-), and Rb+ ionic radius lies between K+ and Cs+, so the lattice constant should be noticeably smaller than typical Cs2MCl6 (a ~10.2–10.4 Å) but slightly larger than the corresponding K-based fluorides. Based on size scaling from chloride compounds in the set (e.g., Cs2MCl6 entries) and known trends that fluorides increase ionicity and widen band gaps relative to chlorides, I predict a moderate-to-wide insulating gap. Formation energies for A2MHal6 compounds in the set cluster around -1.3 to -2.1 eV/atom for stable halides; stronger M–F bonding usually gives somewhat more negative formation energies than chlorides, so a value near -1.6 eV/atom is reasonable. The lattice parameter was estimated by scaling typical Cl-based cubic a-values down for F- and adjusting for the Rb vs K/Cs size. These predictions are approximate and subject to uncertainty from the Co oxidation/spin state, exact structure distortions, and magnetic ordering which can affect the band gap and total energy.

Reasoning: Rb2CoF6 is an A2M X6 elpasolite-like compound (Rb2M6- anion framework). Analogues in the provided set (Rb2MCl6, Cs2MCl6, and A2H6 entries) indicate typical cubic lattice parameters for A2MCl6 with Rb around a ≈ 9.9–10.3 Å (Cl). Fluoride is substantially smaller than chloride (ionic radii F- << Cl-), so a simple ionic-radius scaling predicts a lattice constant reduced by roughly the ratio of F-/Cl- radii (~0.73). Applying that factor to typical Rb2MCl6 a ≈ 9.9 Å gives a ≈ 7.3–7.4 Å; this is consistent with many small-anion A2X6 or A2H6 analogues in the list (a ~7.25–7.6 Å) and corresponding volumes (≈380–440 Å3). I therefore predict a cubic cell with a = b = c ≈ 7.35 Å and volume ≈ 397 Å3 (7.35^3 ≈ 397 Å3).

Band gap: transition-metal (Co) compounds in this family show a range from small gaps to ∼2 eV in the provided data. Co in Rb2CoF6 is nominally in a high oxidation state (Co4+, d5), which can produce narrow d-bands and possible magnetism that reduce the gap; however, the highly ionic fluoride anion tends to increase band gaps relative to chlorides/iodides. Balancing these effects and by analogy to the listed A2MCl6 gaps (many in the ~0–2 eV range) and the larger gap effect of F versus Cl, a moderate semiconducting gap of order 1–2 eV is the most likely. I adopt 1.6 eV as a best single-value estimate.

Formation energy: most A2MCl6 / A2MBr6 entries in the list have fairly negative formation energies per atom (commonly between −1.3 and −2.3 eV/atom). Fluorides are typically thermodynamically favorable (more negative formation energies than heavier halides) but cobalt in a high oxidation state (Co4+) can raise the formation energy (less negative) relative to d0/d10 metals. Balancing these trends and comparing to Rb-based halides in the dataset, I estimate a reasonably negative formation energy around −1.7 eV/atom (i.e., thermodynamically stable but not as extremely exothermic as the most stable Zr/Ti-bearing examples).

Estimated by analogy to A2B X6 halides in the provided dataset. Cs- and K-based A2MCl6 entries give cubic a in the ~9.7–10.4 Å range and band gaps from ~0–2.3 eV depending on metal; replacing Cl with the smaller, more electronegative F shrinks the lattice and typically increases the ionic character and band gap. Rb sits between K and Cs in size, so I choose an a slightly below typical Cl-based A2M6 values but larger than very small hydride cells. Co in a high (+4) oxidation state (d5) in a fluoride environment is expected to be at least a small-gap insulator/semiconductor rather than metallic in standard DFT, so the band gap is raised compared with analogous chlorides. Formation energies for the chlorides and bromides cluster around -1.3 to -2.0 eV/atom; fluoride bonding is strong and should give comparable or modestly more negative formation energy, so I place it in the middle of that range. Given these trends I predict a cubic cell with a ≈ 8.90 Å (b = c = 8.90 Å), volume ≈ 705 Å^3, band gap ≈ 2.10 eV, and formation energy ≈ -1.45 eV/atom. These values carry substantial uncertainty (±~0.3–0.5 eV for gaps and ±~0.2–0.4 eV/atom for formation energy) because of limited direct fluoride and Co4+ analogs in the training set.
